text: Dark brown in color moderate tan head that diminished fairly quickly. Caramel and dark rye dough aromas. Thinner feel, with some acidity and metal. Flavors of caramel and toasted malt. A stronger amber in my book. 2/12
12oz bottle. Poured a brown color with an off white head. Earthy, some breadiness, nutty, and caramel.

(bottle - 12 oz) Dark brown pour with a creamy tan head. Malty and bready aroma with some light hop bitterness. Flavor is pretty standard for the style. Sweet bread malts with a light hop bite at the end.

Transfer from BA review on 3-25-12 - 

Poured from bottle into pint glass 

Appearance  Pours a beep brown color with a huge billowy off white head. The head is very porous with huge bubbles trapped within. The head fades very slowly to give some nice lacing.

Smell  Sweeter toffee aromas are the most prevalent. These are mixed with a bit of banana and some good breadiness.

Taste  Malty through and through. A nice roasted malt flavor is present all the way through the taste experience. Up front it is a bit on the medium dry side and seems to gain sweetness as the taste experience advances; mainly toffee and brown sugar flavors come into play. Toward the end the a little bit of fruit flavors come into play and leave a nice smooth taste on the tongue.

Mouthfeel  The mouthfeel is a bit on the creamier side with a lower level of carbonation. This makes for a very easy drinking and very enjoyable mouthfeel giving the nice malty flavors a chance to really permeate the tongue.

Overall  Very easy drinking with a nice taste profile. I would say it would make a great beer for a lighter fish meal (balancing out the lightness with some nice thick, but not too thick, maltiness) or for session drinking with a friend on a cooler fall day.
(Backlog) 12 oz Bottle. Clear, brown colored with burgundy tinges, and has an off white head. The smell is malts, dough, nuts, rich, savory, and deep. The taste is more basic, malts, roast, and ok.

Appearance:
Deep garnets and burnt ambers under a light khaki head which fades into a blotchy layer that grows thicker as it sticks to the glass.

Nose:
Pumpernickel and dark stone fruits such as prunes and raisins. Tendrils of European chocolates weave in and out. Whole grain breads intermingle with the pumpernickel breads.

Palate:
Smooth silky mouthfeel carry a gentle river of treacle, prunes, and raisins across my tastebuds. Prune infused raisins breads and pumpernickel breads. Slightly dry tannic finish of apple skins keeps it from growing too sweet with the dark fruits. Chocolate truffle powder and nutmeg in the breath.

Final Thoughts:
A fine American craft beer example of a German style dunkel, aka, dark lager. Fresh moist dark breads and fruits truly live up to the standard of liquid bread. A tasteful winner of Samuel Adams honorable LongShot homebrew contest.
The grainy flavor of pale malt has some pot caramel notes coming through as it opens and hints of roasted biscuit malt for a moment in the clean finish. There is a spicy hop hint in the aftertaste.

Sampled on 7/5/2013. This Dunkel pours a dark brown color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized white foamy head. With nice lacing and decent retention. The aroma is fruity and sweet, bready and slightly roasty. A medium bodied dunkel. The malts are roasty, fruity and sweet, hint of dark fruit. The hops are herbal. Decent carbonation. A fairly smooth, slightly sweet dunkel. Its missing the big sweetness that one would expect in a dunkel, but it has enough sweetness to carry the flavor. Very drinkable. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Bottle.  Dark brown color with a tan head.  Smell is slightly spicy, malty, and some hops.  Taste is pretty spot on to any dunkel you would find from Germany.  Rich, malty flavor, high carbonation.  Not a bad effort.

12oz. served into a SA perfect pint.

A - Amber body with an airy tan head that takes its time sinking. Leaves behind a few specks of bubbles on the sides of the glass.

S - Rich malt, steely caramel, sweet bread, molasses, nutmeg.

T - Brown bread crust, toasty, sweet caramel malt, nutty, hints of nutmeg, burnt brown sugar comes out on the finish.

M - Moderate carbonation, medium body, soft and chewy, smooth feel.

Simple, clean, malty, and tasty. I wouldnt seek this out but I would definitely drink it again.

Serving type: bottle

04-09-2012

Brown pour, 2 fingers of off-white head.  Lots of lace here. Aroma of fresh bread, Caramel, toasted malt.   fresh bread up front, rye, caramel, very slight hint of yeast, Malty, toasty, Slightly spicy.  Medium body.  Getting better as it warms.  Wish I had some schnitzel to go with this - a fairly good liquid-bread dunkel.  *bumped up a point as this is getting very drinkable as it warms.

Pours deep brown with an enormous lasting big bubbly head, leaving lots of lace. Bold malty aroma. Smooth creamy, easy drinking dunkel. FInishes sweet. Although not spectacular taste, I enjoyed it. Dry sugary aftertaste.

Nice dark pour with a tan head. Brown sugar and candied dark fruit aroma. The flavor is surprisingly different, yet also very good, than the aroma. Roasted malts and bread with a hint of yeast and spice. This is the best of this style that Ive had, I wish I had found it sooner.

Bottle shared by Tmoney99.  Pours a clear cola brown color with a large yellowish beige head.  The aroma is light but has some doughy bread, grass, light fruits.  The flavor is malt forward; lightly toasted bread, dough, light fruits with a subtle spicy note.  Not bad.

Another thoughtful tick from drabmuh. Thanks Matt.

The beer is dark chestnut with russet highlights when held to the light. The head is light tan colored and leaves sparse lacing on the pint glass.

The aroma is mild, but I get faint whiffs of brown bread, biscuits, lager.

The flavor picks things up a bit, with some grain, bread, a touch of alcohol, and a dry finish. Some fruit and nut characters emerge as the beer warms.

Light in body and pretty smooth sailing, with a lingering lag presence. A touch of bitterness in the finishes adds balance.

Overall, this was ok.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-24-2012

Clear dark nutty amber with a lush pillowy light-khaki head.  Nose of bittersweet deep maltiness, earthy roast, dark toast, and dough.  Flavor had a nice malty earthiness with toast and dough, dark sweetness, a gentle kiss of bitterness, just a little kiss of molasses, and a doughy finish.  Lovely little dunkel.

Almost clear dark deep brown chestnut pour with thin off white head and light lacing .... aroma is roasted and nutty with light caramel malts .... taste is nutty and roasted with a dark fruity yeast and a light spice/bitter hop bite .... light roasted simple and good

12 oz. bottle poured to a SA pint glass showing a clear, dark mahogany hue, with a modest layer of tan froth & bubbles, and ribbony lacing. The aroma presented a toasted, almost roasted nature, with smooth maltiness, cocoa, and a touch of nuttiness. A bit of treacle, moderate, earthy bitterness, and maybe just a hint of sweetness followed the aroma notes into the flavor. With a medium+ body, and appropriate carbonation to accentuate the flavor notes, the finish retained some of the mellow, hop bitterness together with a crisp dryness. A very presentable Dunkel, and a worthy member of this last seasons Longshot medal winners.

12 oz. bottle. Smells of dark roasted malt with hints of caramel and dark fruit. Tastes of thickly roasted malt, molasses, brown sugar, and barley with a hint of dark fruity esters. Thick body and fairly smooth -- though not perfectly. Fairly good.

Appearance: mahogany brown, with lovely dark red highlights.   Aroma: caramel, dark toast, chocolate, toffee, cherries, plums, and roasted nuts.   Taste:  as the aroma indicates.   Finish: smooth, sweet, a little fruity, and with a bit of toasty spices.   Notes: 	Very drinkable, pretty sweet, and nicely tasty.  Not bad at all.

Pours a reddish amber color with a medium tan head that faded quickly with light lacing. Smells of dough, dark chocolate, caramel. Tastes the same ad what I go on the nose with an added peppery note. Mouthfeel is heavy and pretty chewy. Overall this is a pretty solid dunkel with a lot of good flavors.
This is an okay beer. Some fruitiness and malts that go back and forth. The body is fairly heavy and a bit sweet as well. Okay, but not really for me.

Bottled.  Poured medium reddish-brown with a short beige head.  The aroma picked up sweeter chocolate, caramel, and nutty malts with faint accents of dark fruit and peppery rye.  The flavor found more of the dark fruit and nutty notes at the core, with prickly carbonation and rye around.. finished with nice balance between the sweet malts and the roasty spicage.  Light-medium bodied and well-balanced on the palate.. this was one of the best examples of the style that Ive come across.

THOUGHTS: One of the most flavorful dunkels Ive ever tried. Just tons of flavor and aroma.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, dark reddish amber that was nearly brown in the glass with a small, off-white head that kept a thin sheet. The aroma had moderate to heavy caramel, dark bread and milk chocolate; lighter roasted malt; light to moderate doughy and spicy yeast; prune; and hints of cola. The initial flavor was light to moderately sweet and slightly bitter; while the finish was moderately sweet and slightly sour with an average duration. There was caramel, dark bread, spicy yeast, roasted malt, nutty malt, prune, other dark fruit, doughy yeast and milk chocolate. The medium body was syrupy but more more oily with lightly fizzy carbonation and a slightly astringent and lightly metallic finish.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cereal, roasted and nutty, light to moderate herbs, dough and meat for the hops and yeast with a hint of dark brown sugar in the background. Head is large, frothy turning creamy, light tan, with good but thin lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear, dark brown. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes slightly sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Palate is on the lighter side of medium, watery, with a carbonation between soft and lively, and a lightly chalky and metallic finish. A pretty good Dunkel and a great representation of the style.
Bottle pours brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma and flavor are awesome.  Huge bread and nutty malt with really nice yeast character in the finish.  This is a home run.

12 oz. bottle- Pours dark brown to red with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, syrupy, cherries, somewhat yeasty. The taste is malty, again syrupy cherries, not overbearingly sweet, but still sweet, moderate spices. Body is medium, carbonation is moderately low. Overall It was decent, nothing to write home about, but good.

Bottle. Poured a darker amber almost brown color. Smaller tannish head that was gone rather quick. Aroma hints of caramel, molasses, brown sugar, and malts. Very malty flavor. Some syrup, brown sugar and other candies. Medium body. Decent beer nothing all that rememberable.

I got this as part of a mix & match 6pk at Madison East.

Pours a dark brown with an average lasting off-white head. Scent is mostly malts that are toasted and roasted with hints of cocoa. Taste is rich and refreshing. It is full of sweet, malty flavors and a mixture of spices. Great texture and drinkability with a sweet cocoa after taste. Very well made and very impressive for being a home brew winner.
Reddish Black. Actually, I guess blackish red makes more sense. Thin ring of foam. Smells molasses-like. Taste is very malty, a good deal of molasses, and a subtle rum note.
(tasting at Des Peres Schnucks) light brown with off white head. Sweetish malt aroma. Flavor is bready/caramel malt
Clear copper with a thin tan foamy head.  Aroma of dough, toffee, noble hops, sweet caramel and brown sugar.  Taste is a bit metallic with dough, yeast and semi-sweet malt.  Thin and a tad bland.

great translucent mahogany with a thin beige head. slightly syrupy full body with high carbonation.

aroma: rich bready munich malt, slightly sour minerality, and faint herbal hops.

taste: sour minerality, fat bread-crust malt, caramel, and faint peppery herbal hops.
Malty, earthy flavors. Perhaps some notes of toasted almonds and hearty wheat bread. Some slight bitterness, but mostly a toasty mouthfeel. Average stuff.
12 oz bottle.  pours a clear brown with reddish hues.  Aroma of toasted grain, toffee, grass and raisin.  flavor is toffee, peat, roasted grain.  A solid dunkel.

Bottle.  Enjoy before:  08/12.  A deep copper pour with a thick khaki head.  The subdued aroma features some caramel, pears, apples, grains, and the slightest hint of citrus in the background.  Goes down thin to medium-bodied and kinda crisp.  Refreshing and sessionable.  A perfect palate.  Some caramel along with a touch of toasted graininess upfront taste-wise.  A bready/doughy middle.  The finish is just a bit dry with some grassy hoppiness and a hint of smoke.  A little spiciness throughout.

Pours a cloudy brown with a small light tan head. Aroma is quite earthy, with a musty smell that is almost more English than German. There is definite malt sweetness in the aroma, and not much for hops at all. Flavor is similar, very malty and musty/earthy, slightly sweet. Palate is good, not overly carbonated. A nice dunkel, if a bit sweet and a bit musty for the style.

Nice rich brown coloured body with a nice two centimetre tall tan head. Aroma of deep toasted malt, a bit of coffee, some strong caramelised sugars, a bit of pit fruits and a good nuttiness. Medium-bodied; Strong malty flavour with some burnt flavours, a bit of light earthiness, some metal and a hint of light coffee - but mainly the malt and the toffee comes through. Aftertaste is nice and relatively light - no sharpness and no bitterness, just a pleasant malt kick with good sugars. Overall, a very nice dunkel with some good complexity and a good bell curve of a flavour profile. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle from the LongShot six pack purchased at Total Wine in McLean, Virginia on 01-August-2012 for US$8.99/6pack sampled at home in Washington on 19-August-2012.

Bottle from Total Wine in Sacramento, CA. Pours clear cola with a 2 finger foamy beige head. The aroma is quite roasty - but like a toasted bread thing. Body is at least medium. Flavor is nutty/malty with noble hop indications. Its a little bready, but not so much as to be yeasty. Call it balanced. Call it tasty. Finishes towards darkly bready - but with a little less sugar it could be finishing towards an abbey dubbel. Its really good.

Big Top Beverage Mart, Rosyln variety case: Pours a dark amber with beige head. Aroma is sort of bockish: dark fruit with a hefty bit of malt. Beer is very lightly sweet, but the sweetness lingers through the whole quaff. There is a slight hoppy tinge at one point in the drinking of this. Tis a rather good dunkel.

Pours a dark clear almond, chocolate brown with frothy tan-tinged head. Aroma is malty, almond, caramel and brown sugar. Flavor is coffee, brown sugar, molasses. Body is creamy with a lot of carbonation. Light on the tongue.

Bottle. Poured clear dark brown color with an average to large frothy light brown head that was mostly lasting with excellent lacing. Medium toasted malty aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium dark sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of average duration. This beer met my expectations.

Best before August 2012.

A: This is a beautiful beer with a clear mahogany body showing a nice steady stream of carbonation to a rather thick and dense tan head that has great retention.

S: Very malty and sweet, but not cloying. This is a great blend of caramel and toffee, very enticing.

T: This is malty and bready, slightly toasty, with some caramel and a hint of spice on the mid-taste. Sweet, but not cloying.

M: Near full-bodied with light fizzy carbonation.

O: This is a great malty beer, I am enjoying it. It is a nice "full" beer, by that I mean that the flavors and aromas really fill out and leave me satisfied.

poured into a slender pint, the smell comes off heavy soil with spicey bitterness and marvelous chocolate aftertaste.  Color is dark brown, mouthfeel is dry and bitter.  Cocoa comes in to play a short time into this brew, more dry and dusty with some sort of rasin and fig combination.  This is a solid and hefty dunkel.

From bottle. Mild sweet aroma of caramel, roasted malt, and a little bit of metallic or carbonic tang. Dark coppery brown clear with light haze, topped with light tan creamy head. Mild lacing. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation. Starts roasty with caramel and some carbonic acidity. Nice dunkel flavors, with nutty sweet finish topped with mild to medium bitterness. After is semi-sweet, nutty, with a little bitter tang.

Love getting this six-pack every year.  You never know what you are going to get.  This one is pretty sweet up front in the nose and flavor.  After that I get a weird flavor that is not quite medicinal but isnt malty or "doughy"  Just didnt hit my sweet spot.

The aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, nutty, some vegetable.  The appearance is cola red brown, off-white head.  The flavor is caramel, bread, nuts, some cooked vegetables.  The finish is noble hops, light caramel sweetness.  Medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Nice job, Corey!

Pouts deep brown with beige head.  Smells of cinnamon pine and roasted malts. Roasted Malts fade to fried dough but doesnt sit as heavy. Very drinkable. Nice for after dinner

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
dark amber pour with a cream head.  nose is malts, roast, spices, and hops.  easy on the palate, roasted malts, super easy to drink.

12oz bottle from the 2012 mixpack. It poured a clear reddish brown color with great persistent off-white head and Belgian lace. Aromas of husky grains, rising dough, freshly baked brown bread, dark toast, slightly fruity hops and yeast notes. Flavors of a tangy, tart, true-to-style Munich Dunkel albeit a bit roastier. Light-medium body and average carbonation. Well-rounded bready mouthfeel, slight appropriate mineral hardness. Not particularly complex but a very nice drinkable dark lager. I was in the mood for a table-strength beer with some personality after dinner, and this really hit the spot.

You might mistake it for cola if you didnt see tiny upfloating bubbles; brown with a hint of red. Large, pillowy head. The head is a big, thick meringue; the lace is a slush. 

Aroma is mildly sweet, somewhat nutty malts. A little dark caramel, a little raisin, hint of corn syrup. The hop -- what there is of it -- is subdued and grassy. Very pleasant nose.

The sweetness of the malt taste is perfectly balanced by the nutty qualities. Prevents it from being completely saccharine. 

Buttery feel. Slick and very smooth. Perfect for style. The malt is slightly sweet, slightly nutty, well balanced.

12 ounce bottle poured a brown cola color with aromas of dought, roasted malt, caramel, and some light spice.  Flavors are the same, clean aftertaste, nice dunkel, not extremly heavy on the palate.  A nice surprise for sure.
Bottle courtesy of nuplastikk, thanks!  Very dark brown color, thin beige head, decent lacing. Aroma of chocolate biscuit. Taste is similar.

12 oz bottle.  Clear red amber pour with an off-white head.  Cereal aroma with iron, toffee or caramel hints.  Toasty cereal aroma, toffee, some roastier biscuit tones.  Good flavors; straightforward.

12 oz bottle. Pours cola brown with a medium dissipating beige head. Aroma consists of doughy bread, caramel, cinnamon. Taste is sweet and lightly tart. Some dark fruit comes through in flavor. Chewy texture. Enjoyable.

12oz bottle.  Stained glass amber-brown color.  Glass lacing off-white/beige head.  Smooth chocolate-caramel tinged aroma, A really solid, balanced Dunkel.  Mild spicy hop tones give it that great balance, unlike other examples that seem overly sweet, this is quite a nice offering.  Doughy and fresh, the only thing wrong with this beer is the dorky label.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Sweet malty flavor with a lingering finish.
Bottle: Straight forward malty lager. Malty-sweet with a light body, refreshing. Food Pairing: Schweinshaxe.

7/8/12. 12oz bottle thanks to PorterPounder. Nice amber pour with plenty of reds and a small khaki pour. Bready malt aroma with a bit of tartness. Slightly sweet bready entry with a hint of toasty dryness.

It poured a dark brown color with a large tan head. The aroma was of bready malts, some caramel, raisin spice and a little herbal finish. The taste was of toasted malts, roasty, some raisins and a mild hop finish. A very decent Dunkel.
Very toasty aroma.  Very dark larger.  Caramel taste.  Pretty sweet with toasty finish.  Very impressed and unique.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber with a large tan head. Smells of sweet grasses. Tastes sour and grassy. Yuck.

12 ounce bottle from a 6 pack purchased at Nugget in Davis, CA.  The aroma on this is a bit sweet, sugary, and lightly metallic.  Mild spicy and herbal hop character is also present.  A little nuttiness is in there as well.  Transparent dark amber body with a creamy, light tan head.  Quite attractive.  Starts quite sweet, sugary, and a bit cloying.  Some nuttiness follows the sweetness, before this beer just sort of dissipates into nothing.  Slightly metallic finish and faint bitterness.  Something about this beer is just a little too heavy and sweet and sticky for me, especially when I am having a dunkel.  This is closer to a doppelbock than a dunkel.

Clear mahogany with a taupe head that covers for a nice, long time until leaving a collar.  Some garnet highlights on the edges of the beer.  Beautiful.  Aroma of sugary sweet wet grains, almost some sherry like notes as well.  Taste of cereal and roast.  Some bitterness at the very end.  Very long finish of dough covering the mouth long after swallowing.  Tasty!

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark brown color with red highlight and a medium sized foamy tan head that lingered and left good lacing. The aroma was sweetish, tang and malty with notes of molasses and cherry. The flavor was tangy, malty and woody with a bit of nut, cherry and fig. The finish was medium length malty and fruity. Moderately full bodied. Ok.

Bottle from Binnys, bought in April. The familiar malty, grainy smell of a German dark lager greets me under the cap. Pours a big tan head over a dark brown body. Taste has a caramel malt to it, minus the graininess from the nose. Suggestions of dark cherry and a whiff of brandy, then some banana ester. Sticky malt finish. Nice dark beer which seems to get its character straight from malt, no over roastiness.

12 oz. Clear and dark with a lasting disc of foam. Aroma is cocoa, caramel, and espresso. Taste is at first cola, then some cocoa, raisin, and light char. Medium body is a bit to the sweet side and fairly smoothly carbonated.

Pours a cherry cola color with a medium light beige head that diminishes steadily. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of toasted malt, caramel and mild hops. Light to medium body with flavors of bready malt, caramel and earthy hops. The finish is malty with a sweet aftertaste. Decent beer overall.

Picked up the Longshot series from BevMo in Mission Valley, San Diego, Calif. Poured from a bottle into a pint glass. About 1 ½ fingers of head. Color was dark red, almost brown. Light tan lacing on the top. Average retention. 

Smelled dark chocolate and coffee malts. Also some caramel in there, and some dark fruits, mainly cherry. Slighty reminded me of the Sam Adams Cherry Boch. 

First thing that stood out with the taste was the smoothness. Got dark chocolate, light coffee, toffee and cherry. Got some Riesen candy in there as well. 

Medium-to-full body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long-lasting, smooth finish.

Really liked this beer, a bit better than the Longshot Derfs Secret Alt that I just had. Just smooth and consistent.
Deep red/brown...slim tan head, not much lacing.  Malty, yeasty noise.  Malty taste, mixed with a bit of alcohol finish.  Smooth mouthful, minor carbonation.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a dark brown with a thin off white head, the aroma has a good amount of caramel and malt, the flavor is very sweet with a great malt backbone and caramel in the finish, very smooth mouthfeel, good stuff.

Pours a clear brown with amber highlights. Dense mocha head. The aroma is of pumpernickel, wood, caramel, nuts. Light bodied, gentle carbonation. Tastes of toast, chocolate, amaretto. Dry finish. Perfectly smooth and silky palate. Great dunkel.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a large, frothy off-white to light tan head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is caramel, toast, and nutty malt with hints of dates, some earthy and woody hops.  Flavor is malt dominant, light to medium sweetness, notes of dates and cooked pears, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.
A wonderful smooth flavorful beer. the malt is smooth and almost creamy, the hops are very little but does adds a slight punch. carbonated and not to fizzy. to be enjoyed.

12oz. bottle.  Malty and somewhat sweet aroma, with notes of caramel, faint roast, chocolate, hazelnut and black bread, a touch of raisin appearing when the glass is swirled a bit.    Clear deep, dark brown in color with a lasting, fine, ivory head.  Flavor is similarly full of sweet, dark maltiness, more chocolate, breadiness and some very faint dark fruitiness apparent here and there, but this is balanced out rather well by lightly spicy, herbal hop tones and a light-moderate degree of bitterness.  A pleasant roasted nut quality appears towards the finish, which is otherwise clean and malty.  Smooth and creamy on the palate with a low amount of effervescence and a medium body.  Enjoyable, certainly recommended to any fans of the style.

A nicely done dunkel.  With the great name I was hoping for a bit more, but once I found out it was a dunkel, this is as good as it gets.  Amber tinge to the dark stuff, that you can see through.  Not much head or lacing.  Nose is sweet and malty, palate is the same, a bit of caramel malt perhaps.  Some toasted notes too.  Decent session stuff.

The aroma is malty and yeasty with hey like hops and a touch of metal. The appearance is brown with a large head. The taste is like the aroma. The palate is thin. Overall a nice tasting beer but I am not in love with the aroma.

A - Pours a fairly clear ruby-copper with a finger of frothy tannish head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of caramel malts and dark fruit with some nuttiness, brown sugar, breadiness, and a touch of spice.

T - Starts off with a mix of come dark caramel and bready malts. Through the middle, some light dark fruit sweetness comes through with some nuttiness and a bit of brown sugar. The finish is mix of caramelized malts with a bit of bready malts, dark fruit, and a bit of spice.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Nice sessionable lager. The dark malt flavors are nice and provide some rich malty flavor with weighing down the beer too much.

Poured a dark cherry-Coke brown with a none lasting off white head. The fragrance is slight, but seems predominately malt. The taste is malty with a roasted grain notes. Very nice! The after taste is roasted grain. This is a beefy Dunkel. The mouthfeel is medium and smooth.  Would drink again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark red with a finger head. Smell is malty with a bit of red fruit. Taste is rich with a bit of fruit, very drinkable. Pretty good.

bottled in multipack. pours deep brown with red overtones in the light. moderate tan head. aromas of roasted malt, ripe cherry and caramel. fairly sweet with a little bitterness. finish is not in line with the beer just a long skunky mouth feel with the malt trying to break through. decent, but not one of the better ones ive had.

Ruby colored pour with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is very malty with some yeast and banana notes.  Medium bodied, creamy.  Chocolate, banana and some bread flavors.  This is pretty solid dunkel and I have had a few.

This is definitely an Americanized take on this style. And by American, I mean it is somewhat over the top when German brews nearly never are. This has an extremely strong, even exaggerated Munich-malt presence. Its a nice brown color w/ a fine-bubbled but small white head. Nose is rich and wonderful w/ the toasty chocolatey Munich-malt presence I mentioned but it gets just a touch oversweet when you taste it--though there is a light green herbal bitterness in the finish to help balance. Overall, one of the better LongShot brews I can think of in the past few years.
Red brown, clear, color. Medium head and body. Sweet malt taste with a bit of roast. A bit of spice, probably from the yeast.
Moderately dark brown. Caramel malts, more prominent in the flavor than the aroma. Only moderately sweet. Bready, Germanic, to be sure. But in the end the notes arent especially distinctive.Bottle.

Brownish in color with an off-white head.  Sweet malt with molasses and toffee notes being the strongest.  A touch of earthiness, and a nice toasted note.  The flavor has a great molasses flavor with a little earthy and spicy character to it.  Plenty of bread and toast, too.  I enjoyed this one.
Bottle. Clear, brown colored with burgundy tinges, and has an off white head. The smell is malts, dough, nuts, rich, savory, and deep. The taste is more basic, malts, roast, and ok.

Aroma of roasted grains, dark fruit and rusty metal. Very dark brown but transparent. A lot of caramel, some smoke and cookie dough. Syrup but not overly heavy. Surpasses dunkels consistency, gets about halfway to doppel.

Bottle. Pours with a clear bronze hued body with a small, off-white head. Aromas of toasted malts, nutty, maple, molasses, munich, earthy, soil. Flavors are nutty, toasted malts, munich, soil. Malt balance, earthy, slight spicy. Dry despite the malt presence. Medium bubbles, slightly fuller bodied.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $9.99/6-pack. Very good.

Bottle. Pours a dark amber with large creamy beige head lasting awhile leaving spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is raisin malt and yeast. Medium mouthfeel with a roast and caramel and slight mettalic finish. A decent dunkel.

12oz bottle pours clear amber with thin tan head. The aroma pulls up some dusty malt roastiness, dry wrinkled prune like fruity esters, blueberry candy and chocolate malts along with a roasty malt sort of earthiness. The taste is pretty clean and crisp even with this sizable load of various roasted malts. I get nearly dark roasted malts, chocolate malts and a hint of coffee as well as sweet dark fruity esters such as blueberries and prunes. Likeable enough product and an interesting take on the style where this one seems actually light on the yeasty esters.

Malty aroma has an overtone that seems to be molasses in one whiff and caramel in the next. Pours a clear, dark, slightly ruddy brown with a thick, fluffy, beige head that sticks around and also leaves some generous lacing. Malty flavor has some roasted character, as well as nutty, caramel and earthy hints and just a touch of cloves. Firm-bodied texture has a decent amount of tingle. Corey Martin, you have a career in brewing in your future!

Pours a clear deep dark chestnut brown with an ample off-white head.
Inviting nuttly malt aroma.
Good malt sweetness with just a touch of sharpness which detracts a bit.
A pretty decent beer. Its a shame that some of these longshots arent out for a while in six packs by themselves.
Yea...I still dont like this style.  All malt, and doughy is definitely accurate.  Very flat in palate yet fairly carbonated.  Not a fan.

Pours a deep brown with a tan head and lacing. The aroma is malty, with lots of caramel and a small amount of coffee. The flavor is malty too, but not overly so. It has a great semisweet aftertaste where the coffee shows up.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I enjoyed the latest Longshot 6 pack.  Retention in my mug. Smell is malt and an Earthy hop. Medium Sweetness with the light hop bitterness to balanced it.  Creamy texture. This home brewer did a great job creating a German type Dunkel. Well done sir!

Name: LongShot Dark Night in Munich
Date: April 11, 2012
Mode: Bottle
Source: Bullocks
Appearance: hazy dark amber, fine tan head
Aroma: earthy and woodsy aroma, dry caramel, touch of sweetness
Flavor: sweet caramel flavor, lots of earthyness, light woodsy, rich dark caramel
Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 12/20
Rating: 3.1/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: ** /4
Bottle. Sweet malt in the aroma. Some caramel and toasted notes. Flavor is simiar, yet is victim to a cloying finish. Syrupy sweet and a bit much. Tasty, but lacking sustainable drinkability.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.  It pours a dark brown with lots of red highlights and a small off white head.  The nose mostly dark bread with a touch of caramel.  The flavor has bread, a slight metallic twinge, some earth, husk, light molasses, and a touch of bitterness.  Medium bodied with average carbonation leading to a rather abrupt and very dry finish.  I kept taking drinks of this one to figure it out and in minutes this one was done.  Interesting and fairly refreshing.  Not bad.
Pours a brown color with an off white head. Smells of wheat and caramel. Taste is similar. Decent enough beer.

Aroma- rye bread, caramel, toffee, dark fruits
Appearance- dark brown with a pillowy white head
Taste- big bready notes, rye, sourdough, chilies
Palate- medium-bodied, nice mouthfeel
Overall- Decent brew here from Sam.  My least favorite of the three Longshots this year but still unique and obviously drinkable.

The beer pours a medium to dark brown with a large tan head. The aroma is very malty with a ton of toffee and biscuit malt. The flavor is more of the same. The toffee and caramel malt really stands out. There is also a little bit of grass and some lightly toasted malt. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very clean tasting and easy to drink.

Pours a deep, woody brown with a tall tan head.
Aroma is bread, caramel.
Taste is very bready, sweet, a little nut, caramel. a bit of roast chocolate.
Very good....smooth, malty......rich.....a nice beer.

Poured a deep copper-red color with a medium-sized creamy off-white head.  Aroma has lots of dough with caramel and a touch of dark fruit.  Some interesting grain notes in the aroma as well.  Taste also has lots of dough with bread and caramel.  The body is slightly creamy with lots of flavor.  The finish has more caramel and grains with some slightly herbal hops.  Overall very nice.
Bottle. Brown with a beige head. Lightly roasted malts, toasted bread, light toffee sweetness, a hint of earthy hops. Solid, very drinkable.
355ml bottle from knightly spirits. FL VC #20. dark brown tan head. nice toasty, dark malt lager. hella drinkable. best dunkel ive had.
Malty malt malt. Bready, grassy, malty. Sweet caramel malt. A dash of hops and a little more malt.

Bottle, poured a dark copper brown with medium head.  Aroma of caramel, bread, nuts, hazelnut.  Light sweetness taste.  Medium body.  Nice creamy texture.  Softer carbonation.  This is a smooth, good tasting dunkel.
deep red amber. almost brown. big frothy head. rich malty aroma with chocolate tones. malty flavor as well, but a bit thin. ok, but unremarkable.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of roasted cereal malts and toasted dark bread, lager yeast.  Dark brown hue with a small mostly diminishing head that left little lace.  Flavor is medium sweet and light bitterness.   Palate is medium bodied and watery average.  Overall a good Dunkel.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, dark red pour with thin off white head, aroma brought notes of sweet fruits, caramel, toffee, hints of biscuit, earth and grass notes, touch of nuts as well.  Taste is sweet biscuit, bready malts, hints of vanilla, toffee, touch of nutty earth, finishing fairly sweet, Pretty tasty, though a bit sweet.
A fine example of the style.  Filmy beige head, dark brown malty but not too sweet flavour, Lekker bit of hop in the finish.  Caramely aroma.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a clear reddish brown color with a big, light tan head that leaves some lacing on the glass.  Aroma is of sweet, dark fruits (plum/cherry) and malt.  Taste is of lightly roasted malts and dark fruits with subtle, earthy hops.  Light to medium bodied and smooth, with ample carbonation.  Ending is of malt with some spice.

Bottle:  Pours a clear dark orange/brown with a large rocky off-white head, aroma has molasses, dough and cherries, starts and ends lightly sweet with a bready ending, medium bodied with a watery texture and mellow carbonation.
Pours dark red with a small white head. Smells dusty fruity and dash of hops. Tastes buttery fruity and a nice roasted dry finish.

Bottle. Ruby brown beer with a light tan head. Dark fruit and light roast aroma. Malt and light caramel flavor with dark fruit. Medium bodied. Malt and light caramel lingers with dark fruit and light spice.
Amber pour with light tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, a little sweetness. Taste is a nice solid malt backbone. It is a little sweet. A good dunkel. Nice lacing.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a dark brownish mahogany with a thin beige head. Sweet aromas of toffee, bread, graham cracker. Moderate body. Carbonation spot on. This a total malt-bomb, and I love it. Caramel, toffee, coffee cake. Faint ethanol on the finish. Really a great beer. I dig it and I want more. Make this a seasonal!

Bottle.  Pours a clear caramel brown with a  medium sized off beige head.  Sweet malt hits the nose from a distance. A bit of toast on the backside over the sweet malt.  Medium bodied, sweet dark fruit, a nice amount of toast.  Sweet malt, chewy toffee, and a nice balancing toast note.  Could be a bit more body, but still nice and easy drinking.  Very delicate bitterness on the finish.

deep dark brown with creamy lasting caramel head. doughy and substantial without being heavy. a bit slick and a nice malt syrup flavor with caramel sweetness and some light bitterness near the finish. nice malt aroma.

From "Longshot" variety 6-pack. Dark amber-brown pour into thick, beige frothy head that slowly dissipates into sticky cascading lacing and a pillowy pool of foam. Aroma of malty caramel and yeasty biscuit dough. Initial flavor of toasty walnut, biscuit dough, and sweet caramel that slowly fades into a slightly bitter finish with hints of nutty butterscotch.

It poured a dark brown color with a large tan head. The aroma was of bready malts, some caramel, raisin spice and a little herbal finish. The taste was of toasted malts, roasty, some raisins and a mild hop finish. A very decent dunkel.

Not much in the way of aroma. Slightly yeastiness but nothing to really awaken the nose. The look is translucent dark ruby brown. The head fuzzes away quickly. Thin mouthfeel. The saving grace is the bready, roasted malt flavor. A decent dark lager but not my favorite.

Nose is mostly doughy and bready with some burnt caramel and hints of buttery notes as well as yeast. Taste follow suit with  some light hops and a good dose of bread dough and yeast. A tad spicy even. Not bad at all. To me it was like a heavier version of a marzen.

With a deep ruby red body, this beer looked very nice in a glass.The aromas on this dunkel were full of toffee and bread with hints of butter. Nothing too complex about the taste either; just hops yeast and caramel with a pretty thin body. Shared again by OmegaX.

(bottle)  Pours a dark red color with a thin light tan head which leaves a nice coating of lacing.  Aroma is strong of musty lager yeast, pumpernickel bread, toasty malt, and even further bread dough.  A little sour twang in here as well, which makes it smell a little off.  Flavor has a slight bit of dark cherry lurking underneath a rather predominant flavor of lightly roasted coffee overhead.  The finish is dry and is faintly spicy.  Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is restrained.  Overall this is a decent dunkel, and the flavor was really nice.

Location/Date:Bottle on April 21st, 2012.
Appearance:Pours a dark opaque brown.
Aroma:Aroma is of caramel and malt.
Taste:Sweet, doughy, caramel.
Palate:Medium body, light finish.
Summary: Solid example of the style, but I have a high preference for the German made versions.

Poured into a snifter.

3.5 A: Dark brown color. Two fingers of creamy/frothy beige head. Retention isnt too great, but a solid ring of lacing is left.

4.0 S: Light supple roast, lots of caramel, and a light chocolate. Part grainy, part biscuity maltiness.

4.0 T: Clean, roasty, caramel, chocolate. Grainy. 

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Exceptionally smooth.

4.0 D: Solid dunkel with a good flavor and clean crispness.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-07-2012 21:13:47

Dark reddish pour with a nice tan head.  Aroma was rich and malty with notes of nuts and dried fruit.  Gorgeous.  Flavors were lightly sweet, lots of caramel, rich malt with a nutty finish.  Mouthfeel was extremely full for the ABV, carbonation medium to light.  Quite an achievement from this one, a real winner.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2016 12oz bottle from Central Market. Pretty normal looking pour but the aroma tossed me for a loop: I swear it smelled like chalk dust from when you would bang erasers together as a kid. Do kids even use chalk and erasers anymore? Oh right the beer...it was tasty; malty and slightly sweet.

Pours a nice clear brown with beautiful reddish highlights and good ample ring of tan head. Really excellent nutty fruity toasty aroma, and the flavor follows perfectly.  Great biscuit and dark roasty huge malty flavor.  REALLY liked this quite a bit.

A clear, amber-brown pour with a lightly tan head.  The nose is chocolate malt and some roasted grains.  The light body is slightly creamy with average carbonation.  It has a sweet taste that never really fades.
Nice brown color, light tan head.  Aroma of caramel malt, some brown sugar, light yeasty notes.  Flavor is very malty, not too sweet, some bready notes, yeast...not bad!

Longshot series is one of my favorite offerings from Sam Adams - a great competition for the community.  Now the beer: love the color, aroma is sweet malt with a little bit of a spice.  Flavor follows the aroma, and an overall malty brew that finishes clean rather than cloying.  I havent had a ton of munich dunkels but this one might make me a convert.
Pours brown with ruby highlights anda slightly off-white foamy head.  Aroma of grain, molasses, and chocolate.  Molasses, spice,caramel flavor with a hint of grain.  Creamy.  Decent beer!

12 oz. bottle from BevMo - Pours a clear brown color with a one finger thick light tan head.  Aroma is primarily toasted malt.  Flavor is toasted malt and light esters.  Medium body.  I like this one because its not cloying like so many Dunkels and Bocks can be.  A nice beer.

Bottle poured into glass. Amongst all the sours we were consuming that night we decided to switch it up for a palate cleanse. Wasnt too much happening here but there was a good bit of spice in the aroma and flavor.

Bottle: The aroma consists of chocolate, molasses, caramel, and a touch of grain. It pours a dark brown with some orange transparency when held to the light. It has a small khaki head that fades to a thin film within a minute or so. The flavor starts with chocolate and caramel. The finish has molasses, light grain, and a hint of tootsie roll. Its medium bodied with light-moderate carbonation.

Bottle. Dark brown to near black pour with a medium, dense tan head. Aroma is strong malt, multigrain dark bread, caramel, and wheat. Taste is sweet malt, caramel, grains, wheat, light bread dough and dark bready notes. Body is medium with a soft, bubbly carbonation. Finishes with more malt notes, wheat, toasted grains, dark bread and caramel.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, grain, ash, graham cracker, slight soy, light caramel, and bread.  Poured dark amber/mahogany/brown in color with a small, tan head around the edges only.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, brown sugar, dark bread, slight caramel, and slight toasting.  Medium body.  Lightly dry, lightly chalky texture.  Average carbonation.  Medium sweet, malt, brown sugar, dark bread finish is lightly dry.

12oz bottle poured into a shaker. Pours a dark amber with a half finger of off-white head. Aroma of caramel, nuts and roasty malt. Taste is light bitter. Caramel malt with a little spice. Medium bodied with a somewhat sticky texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, not bad. Id gladly drink this again.

Reddish copppery color with a nice tannish head. A good bit of malt at first with a bit of nuts and sweet toffee, then some bread like yeast and a hint of orange zest. A full, round body and smooth finish.

12 oz bottle. Clear mahogany with a small beige head. Aroma is toffee and bready malt. Flavor is rich bready malt, nuts and toffee. Medium body with mild carbonation and a soft, smooth mouth feel. Very nice beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours mahogany with a 2 finger off white head. Nice sticky lace is left on the glass. Dark malt aroma with a touch of yeast/bread dough. Flavor reflects the dark German malt backbone. Flavor hints at dark breads, pumpernickel & oatmeal come to mind. This would be fantastic to drink with a salami sandwich made with pumpernickel bread. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Pretty darn good, Mr. Martin

Bottle: pours a nice dark brown with a small tan head.  Aromas are sweet, slightly roasty.  This shines with its perfect balance of flavor.  Sweetness, bitterness, all playing well together.  Tasty... Wonderful.

Pour is a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma is a excellent dark roasted caramel malt.  Flavor is the same but not as intense.  Big roasted malt with a lot of sweetness and roast towards the end.   Nice showcase of the malts. This is a fine example of the style.

12 ounce bottle, best before August 2012.  Served in a pilsener glass, the beer pours a clear ruby red/brown color with a half inch light tan head that went away quickly.  Theres also a decent amount of lacing.  The beer smells like caramel and toasted malt, nuts, chocolate, and a bit of toffee.  Taste is mostly like the aroma, but theres also a bit of brown sugar and spice (maybe nutmeg?) noticeable.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy with a good amount of carbonation.  Its also smooth and easy to drink.  Another solid brew from the Longshot mixed six pack.  I think its worth trying.
Bottle from bu11zeyes 10K tasting.  Medium pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is light chocolate, toffee, and nuts.  Taste is light chocolate, caramel, toast, and light spice.
Pours dark amber with an off white head. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, bread, and light roast. Flavor is sweet, bready malt, caramel, and a little roast.
Bottle. I lioke dunkels and this one doesnrt dissapoint. It had a nice reddish pour with good notes of caramel toffee and roasted malts. A good blend and sweet finish. Nice.
(12oz bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of nuts, grain, caramel, earth, and cocoa.  Flavor toasted grain, caramel, cocoa, and nuts.
A little weak on the alcoholic content but definitely an enjoyable dark brew. Wouldnt mind seeing this one in a 6

Dunkels have never been a favourite with me, but this was well done, very well done .. . ruby copper .. low foam, only the lightest spots of lacing .. . deep caramel, bread crust and some nuttiness .. . slick mouth .. . pretty good stuff!! .. . . listen billy --- its bobby --- like it matters...
Pours deep ruby with thin white head.  Aroma is bready malts and toffee.  Pretty doughy flavor with a little sweetness.  Palate is thin.  Not too bad.

Pitch black pour with some nice head.  Aroma is very pleasant.  Roasted malt, marshmellow, black licorice, and even some floral and spicy notes.  Interesting taste.  Crisp smooth taste with lots of flavor.  Roasted malt mostly with hints of sweetness and spiciness.  Bready finish.  Very nice beer.

garnet amber with a steady light tan head.  Nose shows some fruit,  very bready, light caramel.  Flavor shows some light caramel and toffee, light spice, bready malt.  Tastes fine but feels like its missing something.  A tad watery as well. Carbonation is a little high and it ends sorta minerally.

Pours a dark amber bordering on brown with a smallish beige head that dissipates quickly and leaves minimal lace. Smells of caramel and dark fruit mostly. Smooth malty aroma with maybe a hint of chocolate if I squint a bit. Taste is fairly smooth with lots of caramel and burnt sugar along with darker fruits in the form of prunes and plums. Maybe a hint of chocolate in there as well. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a solid malty grainy mouthfeel. I enjoyed this one a bit more than the other two in the sixer. It pairs well with chocolate chip cheesecake, but that was a happy accident. Ive had better dunkels, but this one is not half bad.
Pours a deep brown with a rich head. This is a very malty beer. I have not been too impressed with the long shots but this is ok.

Bottle @ home. Pours a dark caramel brown appearance with a brown head. Very nice, rich toffee, dark caramelized nutty aroma that is just a touch nutty and some fruity notes. A bit light bodied. Pretty sweet, caramel malty, big toffee, a touch burnt, a little grainy flavor. This drinks pretty nice though maybe a little light bodied and maybe a bit sweet. Not a bad offering overall and definitely in the upper echelon of American-made Dunkels.

A: Pours a dark ruby-tinged copper colored body with about middling clarity. The three finger light tan colored head fades quickly, but leaves plenty of interspersed lacing on the glass.

S: Caramel, toffee, and toasted malts lead the way, with a solid noble aspect making itself known a bit later on. Not the strongest or most complex smell, but it works.

T: Its pretty simple here, toasted malts mixed with caramel, toffee, and hazelnut; finishing with a grassy, earthy note. Not very flavorful or heavy, but incredibly easy to drink, so Ill be a little kinder with the score. This would pair well with a Mexican dish, such as chicken enchiladas in mole sauce.

M: Lighter bodied with little dryness in the finish, and good carbonation. Can seem slightly watery at times.

O: Decent, but pretty nondescript. Luckily, it manages to have a superbly high drinkability factor, so its good for those who dont want an extreme beer, or those who want something to go along with food. Even though this one is just pretty good, Id like to think that the Longshot 6-pack has been a success overall.

Medium brown, clear, with a one-finger tan had that left pretty nice lacing.  Aromas of rich caramel, toffee, roasted malt and a nutmeg-like spice. Flavors are pretty much the same, with sweet caramel malt leading the way with a touch of dark fruit. Medium body and carbonation, somewhat syrupy/oily mouthfeel, and a pretty clean finish despite the sweetness.

Pours very dark brown with a dark red hue and a tan head.  The aroma has dark caramel, thick smooth malt, toffee, mild anise, roast and thick lager smoothness.  It has a medium body that starts creamy then finishes with a sharper aspect due to the semi-sharp carbonation.  The flavor is much like the aroma with a touch of syrup qualities, but it doesnt make it cloying at all.  The finish throws in some red berry aspects.  This is not my favorite style, but is a very respectable dunkel.

Pours mahogany color with a light tan head.  Sweet aroma with caramel malts, toasted malts, and some dark fruits.  Flavor is similar, decently sweet  with the caramel and toasted malts and the dark fruits.

Mild roasted aroma, with hints of toffee.  Pours a dark ruby red, with a giant light tan head.  Nice roasted flavor, with notes of caramel, toffee, and a hint of spice.  Chewy thick mouthfeel.  This is a solid Dunkel, and a really impressive beer.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma of malt, yeast, and spice.  Taste is sweet malt, yeast, caramel, and toffee.  Mild hop finish.  Nicely done.

12 oz bottle:  A wonderful malty aroma, roasted, toasted notes, and a slightly grassy hop backing.  Appearance is a translucent brownish/black with a tan head that lingers.  Taste is quite nice,  almost buttery texture, nicely bitter, sweet malt characteristics.  Palate is quite carbonated on the tongue with a roasted and malty after taste.  OVerall,  I liked this one quite a bit, just a good brew.  Cheers!

(12oz bottle from Total Wine Arrowhead).  Pours a clear reddish-brown color with off-white head. Aroma has some spice, banana/fruit, pumpernickel, syrup.  Taste is sweet with a little spice/carbonation on the tongue.  Light bitterness.  Medium bodied and somewhat sticky.  Pretty tasty brew, but a little sweet to drink for the evening.
Ruby colored with a dense tan head.   Aroma is munichy with some light vanilla notes, and a whiff of pumpernickel.  Taste is pretty much as it smells with light worty german caramel character.

12 oz bottle from Spirits Crossroads. Poured a thick super dark brown body under a smaller frothy beige head. Aroma is like a combo of dough, nutts, and a touch of chocolate and raisin. Fuller bodied with super strong carbonation and finishes with some sour bitterness. Flavor of wet toast, bad chocolatre, wet nutts, dough. Solid effort but not really my style.

Bottle. Solid dunkel - deep amber pour with a smaller creamy head. Nose is bread and malt. Full palate. Taste is malty, slightly spicy, and overall just has a nice full rich flavor profile. Well done.
Bottle, dark amber with no foam, roast and nuts aroma, flavor is walnuts, roast malts,  brown sugar, toast

Location: 12 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 4/3/12, from the Long Shot 6 pack


Aroma: The nose is sweet malts, some yeast/bread/dough, caramel, and some light roast

Appearance: Pours a clear dark orange-brown color with a lasting beige head and mid-heavy lacing

Flavor: The taste is mid-plus sweet, with a big malty character that is quite similar to the nose

Palate: The feel of this one is pretty creamy, with an average carbonation, and a medium body

Overall Impression: 
This is a pretty solid malty lager.  It has a nice flavor to it, and it seems to be pretty well-made.  I didnt really have any complaints.
Pours a dark chestnut, clear with a big, creamy beige head and lovely lacing. Nose of sweet malts, hazelnuts, and bread. Taste is sweet and slightly bitter on the finish. Mildly dry palate.

12oz bottle 4/4/12 (Binnys Downers Grove)-42° in Lager Glass-Pours a clear cola color with a small off white head. Aroma of hops, caramel, toffee, and spices. Taste of the same with a bit more malt and sweetness. This medium bodied brew is not bad but not a favorite style of mine.
Bottle.  Chocolate coffee malt aroma.  Dark brown color with large tan head.  Lightly sweet chocolate malt flavor with a hint of herbal hops.  Body on the light side.  Pretty good.
Bottle. Strong nose of malts. Dark brown color with a nice tan head. Taste of bread, hay, and other malty goodness. Watery palate. One hell of a dunkel

12 oz bottle. Pours deep amber with a small creamy white head. Aroma is sweet and malty, nice rich malt character, some dark fruit and some doughy notes. Flavor starts with some soft doughy notes, picking a more crisp dark fruit note that remains along with some soft cocoa in the finish, Medium body and a crisp carbonation. Medium body. Nice dunkel.
Sweet roasted malt aroma. Amber color with a medium white head. Light sweet beginning that lasts until the end and develops a mild bitterness in the finish.

Savannah, Ga - Habersham Beverage Warehouse - 12 oz bottle - part of their latest Longshot Series. Very dark brown pour - almost black with a sticky off-white head that leaves a thin trail of lacing. Chewy aroma with bits of chocolate, pipe tobacco, some baked brown bread. Flavor is full bodied and fulfilling. Heavy notes of mixed nuts, unsweetened bakers dark chocolate, some moist canned brown bread. Thick, sticky mouthfeel. Overall - excellent.  Curious if they could make a Dunkel this good on a wide production basis at an affordable price point.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aroma of carmel, toasted malt, yeast, cocoa and light roastiness. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of cocoa, carmel, light roastiness and light yeast with a smooth lingering malty finish.

Dark ruby-amber with a frothy beige head that laces pretty heavily. Aroma of caramel, roast, and molasses. Taste is sweet caramel, toffee and fruit with a mild bitterness. Medium bodied. Killer dunkel.
Bottle: poured a brown amber color with a tan head. Aroma was full roasted malt. The taste is assorted malts some nice roastedness and bubblegum.

Pours clear mahogany into a Sam glass. Mocha head with excellent retention recedes to skim surface. Dark caramel aromas. Dry with sweet malty dark caramel upfront turning to roasted nuts in the lasting dough finish.

Part of the Longshot 2012 six-pack - $9.99 at Total Wine & More in Atlanta, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours out a dark garnet-hued body with a pint-sized, off-white head.

Smell: Largely smelling of thick bread crusts with caramel and sulphured molasses, though not particularly aromatic, with supporting notes of banana, raisin, spice, and wheat.

Taste: Molasses atop toasted bread crusts with a background hint of nutty melted caramel. Moderate sweetness. A tang of wheat develops as fruity hints of banana and plump raisins rolls in. Light hop character, light bitterness leaving some malty sweetness to remain on the smooth, semi-dry finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Overall: I sure could go for an Ayinger Altbairisch Dunkel right about now.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with off white head. Nose/taste of toasted grains, roast malt, caramel, light spices and nutty breads. Creamy mouth feel. Medium body.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear dark brown with a large tan creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma of bready malts, caramel, raisin spice and an herbal finish. The taste is toasted malts, roast, raisins and a mild hop finish. Medium bodied, average carbonation and quite drinkable. Nice.

bottle.  dont see too many dunkels around here.  this one pours a clear brown with a large, foamy, beige head.  nose of light toast and toffee with a hint of nuts.  creamy, lagerish mouthfeel and a medium body.  nuts, dough, toast, and toffee in the flavor.  delicate carbonation.  pretty darn good man.

Bottle from E st liquor: Poured a dark mahogany hue with almost no development of head on top. Aroma is mild and smells of caramel malts and reminds me of a doppelbock. The flavor is rich and sweet with a thick base of malts and could have had me confused that this was a dunkel.  Certainly not in the German tradition of the dunkels Ive tasted.

12oz bottle, LongShot 6pk, Vintage 2012.  Medium brown pour.  Smells of toasted grains, dark malts.  Flavors of sweet malts, toasted grains, nutty, and a touch of spice.  Finishes with a toffee and burnt sugar character.  (3291)

Very large head of medium sized frothy bubbles.  Dusty and chocolaty aroma with some light cereal grains and cookie dough.  Color is a beautiful, crystal clear, crimson brown.  Light malty flavor with some roasted grains, crusty bread, a bit of a spicy note late swallow and some dry and slightly chalky grains.  Dries the mouth out.  light alcohol presence.  This is a pretty tasty brew that is well balanced.  Nice job Corey!

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle with an expiration date of Aug 2012.  The pour is a nice looking dark amber with a short-lived but foamy off-white head.  The aroma is a little malty and a little yeasty with a subtle hop addition. The body is medium. The taste was sweet at first yet a tad astringent as the hops merged into the flavor. Fairly easy to drink though.

Dark ruby pour - nose of toffee, rich Munich maltiness, light dough/yeast - fairly creamy mouthfeel - medium body - toasty and semi-sweet malt is showcased well - light notes of toffee and moderate caramelized sugars - light fruity notes on the tail end - a well-executed dunkel.
Bottle. Sweet toasty malt aroma. Clear brown with a moderate tan head. Nutty toasted malt, anise, spice, saccharine flavor, and a slight dry bitterness. Medium body.

12 oz. bottle served in shaker- poured a transparent darkened brown with ruby highlights when held to a light source, fluffy off white one finger head formed and laced very nicely along the glass, light-medium carbonation.  Aroma of wheat toast, hops, and a little slice of love- awww.  Hits the mouth with a light medium body, malt has just a touch of caramel- and its hard to tell if the caramel was darkened or the malt was, middle has some cream in the middle, finish is lingering yet firm.  Delightful- I better stop before I go to work!
Aroma is light roasted, grainy malts and a slight grittiness.  The flavor is caramel, mildly nutty and slight grittiness.  It was decent, could have done without the grittiness.

Pours clear mahogany ruby colored with 3-finger khaki head.  Nose is vienna malt, doughy plasticy notes, earthy brown sugary notes.  Tastes very malty, with earthy brown sugar and some cinnamon spicy notes late.  Decent balance.

Bottle. Pours clear, dark amber with nice beige head. Aroma has subtle hints of toast, malt and hints of mocha. Flavor is very much the same with a nice light sweetness, a hint of toffee that follows with a subtle spiciness. Light-medium body with high carbonation. Overall, solid brew!
Deep amber color with a rocky tan head. There is a mild caramel malt aroma and a roasted, grainy flavor with a rather sweet undertone.

12oz bottle poured into a Lager glass at 39°.  Color is a deep clear brown with light carbonation and a small tight head.  Aroma is a sweet brown sugar like scent.  It has a lighter medium body with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor is sweet with toffee, vanilla and a light roasted note.  In the after taste a mild bitterness comes out just enough to balancing the sweet flavors and give it a faint dry feel.  Overall its a well done brew, its just not very exciting.

Dark ruby brown pour with a thick off white head.
aroma is toffee, caramel, malt, doughy, light cocoa and herbal spice.
Lighter body than expected.
caramel, dusty,  light herbal hop. medium lingering sweetness in finish.
Solidly drinkable, but not something I would buy if it were by itself and not in the longshot pack.
Bottle from Casa De Oro . Nose is slightly sweet with a touch of roasted malt. Pretty full flavored. Some sweet chocolate and roasted coffee. Maybe a hint of toffee.

Pours a clear cola color with a substantial light tan head.  Aroma is toasted malt and bread dough.  Taste is sweet malt, buttery caramel, and just a kiss of hops.  Smooth and easy drinking, very enjoyable.  Session quality.

Pours a mahogany color with a medium off-white head which fades to a thin ring with some glassy lacing.  Aroma is bready malts, spicy notes, and light caramel malts.  Taste is smooth, full-bodied, spicy notes, bready malts.  Top-knotch!
A solid dunked with representative flavors. Malty character, light spicy notes but very little yeast character overall.
A dark reddish brown beer with a small, quickly dissipating head.  The aroma is caramel and slightly floral.  The flavor is bread and roast cocoa, slightly bittersweet and medium bodied.

Sam Boston Lager glass from bottle. A: pretty light smell, malt and straw with carmel. App: nice dark amber color, very frothy head, light tan in color. T: nice medium sweetness of a dunkel, very true to german originals; great interpretation! Nice malty, carmel, toasty, and bready notes. Same flavors from start to finish. Very well balanced. P: nice bubbles, very smooth, medium-lingering aftertaste.

Bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with a medium-sized light tan head.  Aroma was caramel, a hint of chocolate, some spicy hops.  Flavor was lots of caramelish malt, some toffee and chocolate, some interesting roasty elements, quite a lot of sweetness.  Long, sweet finish.  Medium mouthfeel.

Dark red somewhat brown thick head,creamy.
Aroma mineral/slight metallic malty light roasty.
 Very smooth  creamy malty taste,dark carmel malts slight metallic/minerally,mildly sweet with a clean mild slight chocolate in the finish with a balanced roast very mild bittering ,mild citrus notes,smooth slightly peppery  very slight yeastyness,but  pepper and light bittering /roast balances well with the malt sweetness.Enjoyable.nice malty beer.I would like to see more stronger pepperyness personally but altogether very decent smooth and drinkable/enjoyable.
Bottle. Pours clear dark brown, with an off white head. Aroma is malt and brown sugar, with lesser amounts of hops and spices. Flavor is roasted malt, nuts, add spices. Body is medium to thin.
on tap @GABF-pours amber with a light tan head.  Aroma is soft caramel-medium malt.  Taste is caramel-medium malt, some spice hops.
